form.longName: PhenX PX221301 - Pediatric Quality Of Life
form.preferredDefinition: PROMIS© Version 1.1 Pediatric Profile 25 consists of seven item banks. There is one bank for physical function mobility, anxiety, depressive symptoms, fatigue, peer relationships, pain interference, and pain intensity. For each question, the respondent is asked to reflect on the past 7 days. The pain intensity item bank contains one question with a 10-point answer scale. The other banks each contain four questions, and each question has a 5-point answer scale. PROMIS© 25 is administrated as a self-reported questionnaire for children aged 8-17 or via a parent proxy for children aged 5-17. A pediatric proxy item bank was developed for those aged 5-17 years as part of PROMIS to address the need for health status instruments reflecting the perspectives of both the child and parent in cases where a child is too young, cognitively impaired, or unwell to complete a patient-reported outcome instrument and a parent proxy report is required.

headerInstruction.text: Please respond to each question or statement by marking one button. Physical Function Mobility:

question.questionText: In the past 7 days I could do sports and exercise that other kids my age could do (pediatric_qol_physicalfunction_exercise)
In the past 7 days I could get up from the floor (pediatric_qol_physicalfunction_getup_floor)
In the past 7 days I could walk up stairs without holding on to anything (pediatric_qol_physicalfunction_walk_stairs)
In the past 7 days I have been physically able to do the activities I enjoy most (pediatric_qol_physicalfunction_activities_enjoy)
Anxiety: (anxiety_221301)
In the past 7 days I felt like something awful might happen (pediatric_qol_anxiety_something_awful)
In the past 7 days I felt nervous (pediatric_qol_anxiety_nervous)
In the past 7 days I felt worried (pediatric_qol_anxiety_worried)
In the past 7 days I worried when I was at home (pediatric_qol_anxiety_worried_athome)
Depressive Symptoms: (depressive_s_221301)
In the past 7 days I felt everything in my life went wrong (pediatric_qol_depressive_everythingwrong)
In the past 7 days I felt lonely (pediatric_qol_depressive_lonely)
In the past 7 days I felt sad (pediatric_qol_depressive_sad)
In the past 7 days it was hard for me to have fun (pediatric_qol_depressive_hardto_havefun)
Fatigue: (fatigue_221301)
In the past 7 days being tired made it hard for me to keep up with my schoolwork (pediatric_qol_fatigure_tired_schoolworkhard)
In the past 7 days I got tired easily (pediatric_qol_fatigure_tire_easily)
In the past 7 days I was too tired to do sports or other exercise (pediatric_qol_fatigure_tootired_exercise)
In the past 7 days I was too tired to enjoy the things I like to do (pediatric_qol_fatigure_tootire_enjoyment)
Peer relationships: (peer_rel_221301)
In the past 7 days I felt accepted by other kids my age (pediatric_qol_peerrelationships_felt_accepted)
In the past 7 days I was able to count on my friends (pediatric_qol_peerrelationships_count_friends)
In the past 7 days my friends and I helped each other out (pediatric_qol_peerrelationships_friends_helped)
In the past 7 days other kids wanted to be my friend (pediatric_qol_peerrelationships_kids_myfriends)
Pain interference: (pain_interference_221301)
In the past 7 days I had trouble sleeping when I had pain (pediatric_qol_paininteference_troublesleep_pain)
In the past 7 days it was hard for me to pay attention when I had pain (pediatric_qol_paininteference_attentionhard_pain)
In the past 7 days it was hard for me to run when I had pain (pediatric_qol_paininteference_runninghard_pain)
In the past 7 days it was hard for me to walk one block when I had pain (pediatric_qol_paininteference_hardwalk_pain)
Pain intensity: In the past 7 days, how bad was your pain on average? (pain_221301)

validValue.meaningText: 10 - worst pain you can think of
validValue.description: 10 - worst pain you can think of

protocol.preferredDefinition: PROMIS© Version 1.1 Pediatric Profile 25 consists of seven item banks. There is one bank for physical function mobility, anxiety, depressive symptoms, fatigue, peer relationships, pain interference, and pain intensity. For each question, the respondent is asked to reflect on the past 7 days. The pain intensity item bank contains one question with a 10-point answer scale. The other banks each contain four questions, and each question has a 5-point answer scale. PROMIS© 25 is administrated as a self-reported questionnaire for children aged 8-17 or via a parent proxy for children aged 5-17. A pediatric proxy item bank was developed for those aged 5-17 years as part of PROMIS to address the need for health status instruments reflecting the perspectives of both the child and parent in cases where a child is too young, cognitively impaired, or unwell to complete a patient-reported outcome instrument and a parent proxy report is required.

form.longName: PhenX PX220701 - Disease Progression And Regression 0-24 Months
form.preferredDefinition: The Newcastle Paediatric Mitochondrial Disease Scale (NPMDS) and the Newcastle Mitochondrial Disease Adult Scale (NMDAS) can be used to evaluate the progression of mitochondrial disease. There are three versions of the NPMDS, each for a specific age range (0-24 months, 2-11 years, and 12-18 years). The NMDAS is for adult patients over 16 years. The scales allow for standardization of patient assessment and to improve accurate data collection. The scales are composed of multiple domains: Current Function, System Specific Involvement, Current Clinical Assessment and Quality of Life. Almost all questions provide a score which ranges from 0 to 3, with the following representations: 0 is normal, 1 is mild, 2 is moderate, and 3 is severe. Examples of severity for each question are provided. Depending upon the domain, the questions are either self- or interviewer-administrated, based on a provider's clinical assessment or medical records. There is a manual for each scale, which details the administration, process, and scoring instructions.

headerInstruction.text: The Newcastle Paediatric Mitochondrial Disease Scale (NPMDS) 0 24 months

question.questionText: Date of assessment: (disease_progressionregression_024mo_date)
Age at assessment: (disease_progressionregression_024mo_age)
Parental consanguinity: (disease_progressionregression_024mo_parental_consanguinity)
Age at presentation: (disease_progressionregression_024mo_parental_agepresentation)
Age at clinical diagnosis: (disease_progressionregression_024mo_parentalage_agedx)
Genotype if known: (disease_progressionregression_024mo_genotype)
Biochemical phenotype if known: (disease_progressionregression_024mo_biochemical_phenotype)
Basis of clinical diagnosis e.g. MRI, blood / CSF lactate (disease_progressionregression_024mo_basis_diagnosis)
Information regarding pregnancy: reduced fetal movements. (disease_progressionregression_024mo_reduced_fetalmovement)
Information regarding pregnancy: cardiomyopathy on antenatal scans (disease_progressionregression_024mo_pregnancy_cardiomyopathy_antenatal)
Information regarding pregnancy: abnormalities on fetal anomaly scan (disease_progressionregression_024mo_abnormalities_fetalscan)
Please specify (disease_progressionregression_024mo_abnormalities_specify)
Other (disease_progressionregression_024mo_pregnancy_cardiomyopathy_pregnancyother)
Neonatal information: gestational age ____weeks (disease_progressionregression_024mo_neonatal_gestationalage)
Neonatal information: delivery method (NVD vs instrumental vs C/S) (disease_progressionregression_024mo_neonatal_deliverymethod)
Neonatal information: birth weight in kg (disease_progressionregression_024mo_neonatal_birthweight)
Neonatal information: Resuscitation and ventilation (disease_progressionregression_024mo_neonatal_resuscitationventilation)
Specify (disease_progressionregression_024mo_neonatal_specify)

Section I: Current Function Rate function during the preceding 2 week period only according to caregiver interview. Indicate the score that best fits patient's functional status independently of the nature of the signs. (instructions_220701)
Rate function during the preceding 2 week period only according to caregiver Vision (disease_progressionregression_024mo_currentfunction_vision)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild. Limited eye or head movement to large objects or parental face in visual field
validValue.description: 1. Mild. Limited eye or head movement to large objects or parental face in visual field

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. No response to large objects or parental face in the visual field
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. No response to large objects or parental face in the visual field

question.questionText: Rate function during the preceding 2 week period only according to caregiver Hearing (disease_progressionregression_024mo_currentfunction_hearing)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild. Body, head or eye movement only to loud noise
validValue.description: 1. Mild. Body, head or eye movement only to loud noise

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. No reaction to loud noise
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. No reaction to loud noise

question.questionText: Rate function during the preceding 2 week period only according to caregiver communication (assessed with appropriate regard for age) (disease_progressionregression_024mo_currentfunction_communication)

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. Communication unintelligible to parents or completely reliant on non-verbal communication
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. Communication unintelligible to parents or completely reliant on non-verbal communication

validValue.meaningText: 3. Severe. Not communicating effectively in any form
validValue.description: 3. Severe. Not communicating effectively in any form

question.questionText: Rate function during the preceding 2 week period only according to caregiver Feeding (disease_progressionregression_024mo_currentfunction_feeding)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild. Difficulties in sucking / coughing / anorexia / wheezy with feeds or occasional choking
validValue.description: 1. Mild. Difficulties in sucking / coughing / anorexia / wheezy with feeds or occasional choking

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. Supplementary enteral feeding or recurrent aspiration pneumonia
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. Supplementary enteral feeding or recurrent aspiration pneumonia

validValue.meaningText: 3. Severe. Exclusive enteral feeding (gastrostomy / NG tube). Nil by mouth
validValue.description: 3. Severe. Exclusive enteral feeding (gastrostomy / NG tube). Nil by mouth

question.questionText: Rate function during the preceding 2 week period only according to caregiver Mobility (disease_progressionregression_024mo_currentfunction_mobility)

validValue.meaningText: 0. Normal. No concerns. Age appropriate mobility
validValue.description: 0. Normal. No concerns. Age appropriate mobility

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild. Clumsy age appropriate mode of mobility
validValue.description: 1. Mild. Clumsy age appropriate mode of mobility

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. Mobile but through age inappropriate mode
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. Mobile but through age inappropriate mode

question.questionText: Section II: System Specific Involvement Rate system specific involvement during the preceding 6 month period only (or since birth if the child is less than 6 months old) unless otherwise stated in the question. Scores should be assigned according to caregiver interview, clinician's knowledge of the patient and clinical notes (section_ii_220701)

Rate system specific involvement during the preceding 6 month period only (or since birth if the child is less than 6 months old) unless otherwise stated in the question. Seizures (disease_progressionregression_024mo_systeminvolvement_seizures)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild. Myoclonic or absence seizures only or < 1 generalised tonic-clonic seizure/month
validValue.description: 1. Mild. Myoclonic or absence seizures only or < 1 generalised tonic-clonic seizure/month

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. > 5 generalized tonic-clonic seizures/month or > 20 absence or myoclonic seizures/month
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. > 5 generalized tonic-clonic seizures/month or > 20 absence or myoclonic seizures/month

validValue.meaningText: 3. Severe. Status epilepticus or intractable seizures
validValue.description: 3. Severe. Status epilepticus or intractable seizures

question.questionText: Rate system specific involvement during the preceding 6 month period only (or since birth if the child is less than 6 months old) unless otherwise stated in the question. Encephalopathy (disease_progressionregression_024mo_systeminvolvement_encephalopathy)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild. Abnormal sleepiness / lethargy. Waking only for feeds
validValue.description: 1. Mild. Abnormal sleepiness / lethargy. Waking only for feeds

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. Recurrent episodes of mild encephalopathy (> 2/year)
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. Recurrent episodes of mild encephalopathy (> 2/year)

validValue.meaningText: 3. Severe. Life threatening encephalopathy - requires artificial ventilation
validValue.description: 3. Severe. Life threatening encephalopathy - requires artificial ventilation

question.questionText: Rate system specific involvement during the preceding 6 month period only (or since birth if the child is less than 6 months old) unless otherwise stated in the question. Gastrointestinal (disease_progressionregression_024mo_systeminvolvement_gastrointestinal)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild. Constipation or unexplained vomiting / diarrhoea > 3/week
validValue.description: 1. Mild. Constipation or unexplained vomiting / diarrhoea > 3/week

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. Severe constipation (no relief with laxative treatment) or unexplained vomiting / diarrhoea every day or surgical intervention for dysmotility
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. Severe constipation (no relief with laxative treatment) or unexplained vomiting / diarrhoea every day or surgical intervention for dysmotility

question.questionText: Rate system specific involvement during the preceding 6 month period only (or since birth if the child is less than 6 months old) unless otherwise stated in the question. Endocrine (disease_progressionregression_024mo_systeminvolvement_endocrine)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild. Biochemical evidence of impaired function
validValue.description: 1. Mild. Biochemical evidence of impaired function

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. Endocrine failure requiring replacement therapy
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. Endocrine failure requiring replacement therapy

validValue.meaningText: 3. Severe. Endocrine decompensation (e.g. diabetic ketoacidosis, Addisonian crisis)
validValue.description: 3. Severe. Endocrine decompensation (e.g. diabetic ketoacidosis, Addisonian crisis)

question.questionText: Rate system specific involvement during the preceding 6 month period only (or since birth if the child is less than 6 months old) unless otherwise stated in the question. respiratory (disease_progressionregression_024mo_systeminvolvement_respiratory)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild. Abnormal respiratory pattern not requiring therapy / hospitalization
validValue.description: 1. Mild. Abnormal respiratory pattern not requiring therapy / hospitalization

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. Abnormal respiration requiring oxygen flow or hospitalisation but not ventilation
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. Abnormal respiration requiring oxygen flow or hospitalisation but not ventilation

validValue.meaningText: 3. Severe. Abnormal respiration requiring artificial ventilation
validValue.description: 3. Severe. Abnormal respiration requiring artificial ventilation

question.questionText: Rate system specific involvement during the preceding 6 month period only (or since birth if the child is less than 6 months old) unless otherwise stated in the question. cardiovascular (disease_progressionregression_024mo_systeminvolvement_cardiovascular)

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. Abnormal echocardiogram (e.g. cardiomegaly) or sustained / symptomatic arrhythmia on ECG
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. Abnormal echocardiogram (e.g. cardiomegaly) or sustained / symptomatic arrhythmia on ECG

validValue.meaningText: 3. Severe. Decompensated cardiomyopathy or requiring pacing device / defibrillator / ablation
validValue.description: 3. Severe. Decompensated cardiomyopathy or requiring pacing device / defibrillator / ablation

question.questionText: Rate system specific involvement during the preceding 6 month period only (or since birth if the child is less than 6 months old) unless otherwise stated in the question. Renal (disease_progressionregression_024mo_systeminvolvement_renal)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild. Impaired function but no change in diet or therapy required
validValue.description: 1. Mild. Impaired function but no change in diet or therapy required

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. Impaired function requiring restricted protein diet
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. Impaired function requiring restricted protein diet

question.questionText: Rate system specific involvement during the preceding 6 month period only (or since birth if the child is less than 6 months old) unless otherwise stated in the question. Liver (disease_progressionregression_024mo_systeminvolvement_liver)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild. Mildly impaired Liver Function Tests (LFTs). Normal albumin and coagulation. No symptoms of hepatic failure
validValue.description: 1. Mild. Mildly impaired Liver Function Tests (LFTs). Normal albumin and coagulation. No symptoms of hepatic failure

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. Impaired LFTs with symptoms (e.g. jaundice, coagulation anomalies, oedema)
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. Impaired LFTs with symptoms (e.g. jaundice, coagulation anomalies, oedema)

validValue.meaningText: 3. Severe. Failure requiring hospitalisation and / or transplantation
validValue.description: 3. Severe. Failure requiring hospitalisation and / or transplantation

question.questionText: Rate system specific involvement during the preceding 6 month period only (or since birth if the child is less than 6 months old) unless otherwise stated in the question. blood (disease_progressionregression_024mo_systeminvolvement_blood)

validValue.meaningText: 3. Severe. Pancytopenia requiring regular transfusion / transplantation
validValue.description: 3. Severe. Pancytopenia requiring regular transfusion / transplantation

question.questionText: Section III: Current Clinical Assessment Rate current status according to the clinician's examination at the time of assessment unless otherwise stated in the question. (section_iii_220701)

Rate current status according to the clinician's examination at the time of assessment unless otherwise stated in the question. Growth (weight) over preceding 6 months (disease_progressionregression_024mo_currentclinical_growthweight)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild. Weight less than second centile but growing parallel to it
validValue.description: 1. Mild. Weight less than second centile but growing parallel to it

validValue.meaningText: 3. Severe. Weight crossing >= 2 centiles or less than 2nd centile with divergent trajectory
validValue.description: 3. Severe. Weight crossing >= 2 centiles or less than 2nd centile with divergent trajectory

question.questionText: IMAGE disease_progression_and_regression (disease_progression_and_regression)

Rate current status according to the clinician's examination at the time of assessment unless otherwise stated in the question. Development over preceding 4 months __ Score (disease_progressionregression_024mo_currentclinical_development)

validValue.meaningText: Development is not age appropriate, child has not regressed in any area of development, child is not globally delayed in development, AND (1) evidence of delayed speech, language or hearing, or (2) evidence of delayed motor milestones, or (3) evidence of delay in social development, AND there is development progress
validValue.description: Development is not age appropriate, child has not regressed in any area of development, child is not globally delayed in development, AND (1) evidence of delayed speech, language or hearing, or (2) evidence of delayed motor milestones, or (3) evidence of delay in social development, AND there is development progress

validValue.meaningText: Development is not age appropriate, child has not regressed in any area of development, child is not globally delayed in development, AND (1) evidence of delayed speech, language or hearing, or (2) evidence of delayed motor milestones, or (3) evidence of delay in social development, AND there is NO development progress
validValue.description: Development is not age appropriate, child has not regressed in any area of development, child is not globally delayed in development, AND (1) evidence of delayed speech, language or hearing, or (2) evidence of delayed motor milestones, or (3) evidence of delay in social development, AND there is NO development progress

validValue.meaningText: Development is not age appropriate, child has not regressed in any area of development, child is globally delayed in development, but there is developmental progress
validValue.description: Development is not age appropriate, child has not regressed in any area of development, child is globally delayed in development, but there is developmental progress

validValue.meaningText: Development is not age appropriate, child has not regressed in any area of development, child is globally delayed in development, and there is no developmental progress
validValue.description: Development is not age appropriate, child has not regressed in any area of development, child is globally delayed in development, and there is no developmental progress

validValue.meaningText: Development is not age appropriate and child has regressed in an area of development
validValue.description: Development is not age appropriate and child has regressed in an area of development

question.questionText: Rate current status according to the clinician's examination at the time of assessment unless otherwise stated in the question. Vision (disease_progressionregression_024mo_currentclinical_vision)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild. Impaired fixation and / or tracking of small objects
validValue.description: 1. Mild. Impaired fixation and / or tracking of small objects

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. Impaired fixation and / or tracking of familiar faces
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. Impaired fixation and / or tracking of familiar faces

validValue.meaningText: 3. Severe. No response to light or registered blind
validValue.description: 3. Severe. No response to light or registered blind

question.questionText: Rate current status according to the clinician's examination at the time of assessment unless otherwise stated in the question. Ptosis and Eye Movement (disease_progressionregression_024mo_currentclinical_ptosiseyemovement)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild. Gaze evoked nystagmus or unilateral ptosis or impaired eye movement at extremities
validValue.description: 1. Mild. Gaze evoked nystagmus or unilateral ptosis or impaired eye movement at extremities

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. Intermittent nystagmus at rest or bilateral ptosis not obscuring pupils or restriction of >50% eye movement
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. Intermittent nystagmus at rest or bilateral ptosis not obscuring pupils or restriction of >50% eye movement

validValue.meaningText: 3. Severe. Continuous nystagmus at rest or bilateral ptosis obscuring pupils or only a flicker of eye movement
validValue.description: 3. Severe. Continuous nystagmus at rest or bilateral ptosis obscuring pupils or only a flicker of eye movement

question.questionText: Rate current status according to the clinician's examination at the time of assessment unless otherwise stated in the question. Myopathy (disease_progressionregression_024mo_currentclinical_myopathy)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild. Mild symmetrical weakness of hip and / or shoulder girdle only
validValue.description: 1. Mild. Mild symmetrical weakness of hip and / or shoulder girdle only

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. Moderate symmetrical weakness (proximal > distal) limiting functional movement
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. Moderate symmetrical weakness (proximal > distal) limiting functional movement

validValue.meaningText: 3. Severe. Wheelchair / carrier dependent or respiratory compromise due to myopathy.
validValue.description: 3. Severe. Wheelchair / carrier dependent or respiratory compromise due to myopathy.

question.questionText: Rate current status according to the clinician's examination at the time of assessment unless otherwise stated in the question. Pyramidal (disease_progressionregression_024mo_currentclinical_pyramidal)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild. Unilateral pyramidal signs but retaining functional movement
validValue.description: 1. Mild. Unilateral pyramidal signs but retaining functional movement

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. Dense hemiplegia with little movement of affected side
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. Dense hemiplegia with little movement of affected side

validValue.meaningText: 3. Severe. Bilateral pyramidal weakness with little or no movement
validValue.description: 3. Severe. Bilateral pyramidal weakness with little or no movement

question.questionText: Rate current status according to the clinician's examination at the time of assessment unless otherwise stated in the question. Extrapyramidal (disease_progressionregression_024mo_currentclinical_extrapyramidal)

validValue.meaningText: 1. Mild. Unilateral extrapyramidal posturing and increased tone
validValue.description: 1. Mild. Unilateral extrapyramidal posturing and increased tone

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. Bilateral extrapyramidal posturing and increased tone
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. Bilateral extrapyramidal posturing and increased tone

validValue.meaningText: 3. Severe. Severe extrapyramidal posturing resulting in very little movement
validValue.description: 3. Severe. Severe extrapyramidal posturing resulting in very little movement

question.questionText: Rate current status according to the clinician's examination at the time of assessment unless otherwise stated in the question. Neuropathy (disease_progressionregression_024mo_currentclinical_neuropathy)

validValue.meaningText: 2. Moderate. Sensory ataxia or motor impairment (distal weakness) but mobile
validValue.description: 2. Moderate. Sensory ataxia or motor impairment (distal weakness) but mobile

validValue.meaningText: 3. Severe. Reliant on mobility aids primarily due to neuropathy
validValue.description: 3. Severe. Reliant on mobility aids primarily due to neuropathy

question.questionText: Section IV: Quality of Life This survey asks for your views about your child's recent health. Please answer every question by selecting the phrase which best describes your answer. (section_iv_220701)
During the past 4 weeks, how would you rate your child's overall health? (disease_progressionregression_024mo_qol_overallhealth)
During the past 4 weeks, how much did your child's physical health problems limit their physical activities (such as moving or playing)? (disease_progressionregression_024mo_qol_phsyicalactivities)
During the past 4 weeks, how much energy did your child have? (disease_progressionregression_024mo_qol_energy)
During the past 4 weeks, how much bodily pain / discomfort did your child have? (disease_progressionregression_024mo_qol_pain)
During the past 4 weeks, how would you rate your child's behavior compared with other children his / her age? (disease_progressionregression_024mo_qol_behavior)

During the past 4 weeks, how would you rate your child's ability to interact with other people (e.g. with you, siblings or other children his / her age) compared with other children his / her age? (disease_progressionregression_024mo_qol_interactions)

During the past 4 weeks, how much were you (the parent / carer) bothered by emotional problems (e.g. feelings of anxiety, sadness) as a result of your child's illness? (disease_progressionregression_024mo_qol_emotionalproblems)
During the past 4 weeks, how much was your time limited as a result of your child's illness? (disease_progressionregression_024mo_qol_timelimited)
During the past 4 weeks, how much were your family's activities limited or interrupted as a result of your child's illness? (disease_progressionregression_024mo_qol_activitieslimited)
During the past 6 months, what has been the financial cost of your child's illness? (disease_progressionregression_024mo_qol_financialcost)
During the past 4 weeks, how would you rate your family's ability to get along with one another? (disease_progressionregression_024mo_qol_getalong)

During the past 4 weeks, how often did your child's illness have a positive effect on your child, you or your family (e.g. being treated well due to illness, meeting new people)? (disease_progressionregression_024mo_qol_positiveeffects)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Newcastle Paediatric Mitochondrial Disease Scale (NPMDS) and the Newcastle Mitochondrial Disease Adult Scale (NMDAS) can be used to evaluate the progression of mitochondrial disease. There are three versions of the NPMDS, each for a specific age range (0-24 months, 2-11 years, and 12-18 years). The NMDAS is for adult patients over 16 years. The scales allow for standardization of patient assessment and to improve accurate data collection. The scales are composed of multiple domains: Current Function, System Specific Involvement, Current Clinical Assessment and Quality of Life. Almost all questions provide a score which ranges from 0 to 3, with the following representations: 0 is normal, 1 is mild, 2 is moderate, and 3 is severe. Examples of severity for each question are provided. Depending upon the domain, the questions are either self- or interviewer-administrated, based on a provider's clinical assessment or medical records. There is a manual for each scale, which details the administration, process, and scoring instructions.

form.longName: PhenX PX221501 - Scoliosis Quality Of Life
form.preferredDefinition: The Pediatric Outcomes Data Collection Instrument (PODCI) was developed by the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons®, Pediatric Orthopaedic Society of North America, American Academy of Pediatrics, and Shriners Hospitals. The protocol here is based on Version 2.0 of the PODCI which was revised, renumbered, and reformatted in August 2005. The PODCI consists of 86 items and is designed to collect data regarding an individual's general health and problems related to bone and muscle conditions. This instrument is completed by parents (or caregivers) of children aged 2-10 years old. Note: this protocol applies to the three major types of scoliosis; however, only congenital and syndromic scoliosis apply to rare genetic conditions.

question.questionText: Clinic ID of Patient (scoliosis_qol_clinic_id)
Physician ID (scoliosis_qol_physician_id)
First sitx letters of patient's last name (scoliosis_qol_firstsix_last_name)
Office Chart # (scoliosis_qol_office_chart)
Primary DX DX Code (scoliosis_qol_primarydx_dxcode)
Primary DX ICD9 Code (scoliosis_qol_primarydx_icd9)
Primary DX TX Procedure Code (scoliosis_qol_primarydx_txprocedurecpt_code)
Primary DX CPT Code (scoliosis_qol_primarydx_txprocedureicd9_code)
Primary DX CPT Date (scoliosis_qol_primarydx_cpt_date)
Primary DX Side of body procedure was performed on: Right, Left, Both, N/A (scoliosis_qol_primarydx_procedure_bodysite)
Secondary DX 1 DX Code (scoliosis_qol_secondardx1_dxcode)
Secondary DX 1 ICD9 Code (scoliosis_qol_secondardx1_icd9)
Secondary DX 1 TX Procedure Code (scoliosis_qol_secondarydx1_txprocedurecpt_code)
Secondary DX 1 CPT Code (scoliosis_qol_secondarydx1_txprocedureicd9_code)
Secondary DX 1 CPT Date (scoliosis_qol_secondarydx1_cpt_date)
Secondary DX1 Side of body procedure was performed on: Right, Left, Both, N/A (scoliosis_qol_secondardx1_procedure_bodysite)
Secondary DX 2 DX Code (scoliosis_qol_secondardx2_dxcode)
Secondary DX 2 ICD9 Code (scoliosis_qol_secondardx2_icd9)
Secondary DX 2 TX Procedure Code (scoliosis_qol_secondarydx2_txprocedurecpt_code)
Secondary DX 2 CPT Code (scoliosis_qol_secondarydx2_txprocedureicd9_code)
Secondary DX 2 CPT Date (scoliosis_qol_secondarydx2_cpt_date)
Secondary DX2 Side of body procedure was performed on: Right, Left, Both, N/A (scoliosis_qol_secondardx2_procedure_bodysite)

Some kind of problems can make it hard to do many activities, such as eating, bathing, school work, and playing with friends. We would like to find out how your child is doing. (Choose one response for each question) (instructions_221501)
During the last week was it easy or hard for your child to lift heavy books? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_liftbooks)
During the last week was it easy or hard for your child to Pour a half gallon of milk? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_pourmilk)
During the last week was it easy or hard for your child to Open a jar that has been opened before? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_openjar)
During the last week was it easy or hard for your child to use a fork and spoon? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_forkspoon)
During the last week was it easy or hard for your child to comb his/her hair? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_combhair)
During the last week was it easy or hard for your child to button buttons? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_buttons)
During the last week was it easy or hard for your child to put on his/her coat? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_puton_coat)
During the last week was it easy or hard for your child to write with a pencil? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_writepencil)
On average, over the last 12 months, how often did your child miss school (preschool, day care, camp, etc.) because of his/her health? (scoliosis_qol_last12mo_missschool)

validValue.meaningText: 3 - Tow or three times a month

question.questionText: During the last week how happy has your child been with how he/she looks? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_happylooks)

During the last week, how much of the time did your child feel sick and tired? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_sicktired)
During the last week, how much of the time were your child full of pep and energy? (scoliosis_qol_lastweek_fullenergy)
During the last week, how much of the time did pain or discomfort interfere with your child's activities? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_paininterfere)
During the last week, has it been easy or hard for your child to run short distances? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_run)
During the last week, has it been easy or hard for your child to bicycle or tricycle? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_bicycletricycle)

During the last week, has it been easy or hard for your child to climb one flight of stairs? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_1flightstairs)
During the last week, has it been easy or hard for your child to walk more than a mile? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_walkmile)
During the last week, has it been easy or hard for your child to walk three blocks? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_walkthreeblocks)
During the last week, has it been easy or hard for your child to walk one block? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_walkoneblock)
During the last week, has it been easy or hard for your child to get on and off a bus? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_getonoffbus)
How often does your child need help from another person for walking and climbing? (Choose one response.) (scoliosis_qol_child_need_help)
How often does your child use assistive devices (such as braces, crutches, or wheelchair) for walking and climbing? (Choose one response.) (scoliosis_qol_child_use_assistivedevices)
During the last week, has it been easy or hard for your child to stand while washing his/her hands and face at a sink? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_standsink)
During the last week, has it been easy or hard for your child to sit in a regular chair without holding on? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_sitchair)
During the last week, has it been easy or hard for your child to get on and off a toilet or chair? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_onofftoilet)
During the last week, has it been easy or hard for your child to get in and out of bed? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_inoutbed)
During the last week, has it been easy or hard for your child to turn door knobs? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_turndoorknobs)
During the last week, has it been easy or hard for your child to bend over from a standing position and pick up something off the floor? (scoliosis_qol_last_week_bendover)
How often does your child need help from another person for sitting and standing? (scoliosis_qol_help_sittingstanding)
. How often does your child use assistive devices (such as braces, crutches, or wheelchair) for sitting and standing? (scoliosis_qol_use_assistivedevices_sitstand)

Can your child participate in recreational outdoor activities with other children the same age? (For example: bicycling, tricycling, skating, hiking, jogging) (Choose one response.) (scoliosis_qol_recreational_outdooractivities)

question.questionText: Is it easy or hard for your child to make friends with children his/her own age? (Choose one response.) (scoliosis_qol_easy_makefriends)
How much pain has your child had during the last week? (Choose one response.) (scoliosis_qol_lastweek_pain)

During the last week, how much did pain interfere with your child's normal activities (including at home, outside of the home, and at school)? (Choose one response.) (scoliosis_qol_lastweek_paininterfere)
What expectations do you have for your child's treatment? As a result of my child's treatment, I expect my child to have pain relief. (scoliosis_qol_txexpectations_painrelief)
What expectations do you have for your child's treatment? As a result of my child's treatment, I expect my child to look better. (scoliosis_qol_txexpectations_lookbetter)
What expectations do you have for your child's treatment? As a result of my child's treatment, I expect my child to feel better about himself/herself. (scoliosis_qol_txexpectations_feelbetterself)
What expectations do you have for your child's treatment? As a result of my child's treatment, I expect my child to sleep more comfrotably. (scoliosis_qol_txexpectations_sleep)
What expectations do you have for your child's treatment? As a result of my child's treatment, I expect my child to be able to do activities at home. (scoliosis_qol_txexpectations_activitieshome)
What expectations do you have for your child's treatment? As a result of my child's treatment, I expect my child to be able to do more at school. (scoliosis_qol_txexpectations_domore_school)

What expectations do you have for your child's treatment? As a result of my child's treatment, I expect my child To be able to do more play or recreational activities (biking, walking, doing things with friends). (scoliosis_qol_txexpectations_domore_play)
What expectations do you have for your child's treatment? As a result of my child's treatment, I expect my child to be able to do more sports. (scoliosis_qol_txexpectations_domore_sports)

What expectations do you have for your child's treatment? As a result of my child's treatment, I expect my child to be free from pain or disability as an adult. (scoliosis_qol_txexpectations_freeofpain_nodisabilityadult)
If your child had to spend the rest of his/her life with his/her bone and muscle condition as it is right now, how would you feel about it? (scoliosis_qol_nochangedx_howyoufeel)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Pediatric Outcomes Data Collection Instrument (PODCI) was developed by the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons®, Pediatric Orthopaedic Society of North America, American Academy of Pediatrics, and Shriners Hospitals. The protocol here is based on Version 2.0 of the PODCI which was revised, renumbered, and reformatted in August 2005. The PODCI consists of 86 items and is designed to collect data regarding an individual's general health and problems related to bone and muscle conditions. This instrument is completed by parents (or caregivers) of children aged 2-10 years old. Note: this protocol applies to the three major types of scoliosis; however, only congenital and syndromic scoliosis apply to rare genetic conditions.

form.preferredDefinition: The World Health Organization (WHO) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) growth charts include both standard graph lines and a series of percentile curves that demonstrate the distribution of certain body measurements in individuals. Each growth chart may illustrate a specific gender and age range. The percentile curves on each chart depend on which measurement is being recorded. The percentile curves on the WHO and CDC growth charts are for individuals who appear to be unaffected by a condition impacting growth. To provide information for special populations, growth charts for specific conditions have been developed; these growth charts contain percentile curves for the distribution of body measurements in individuals with the specific condition. Some conditions with a specific growth chart are cerebral palsy, achondroplasia, Turner syndrome, and Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).

question.questionText: 1 Obtain accurate measurements When weighing and measuring children, follow procedures that yield accurate measurements and use equipment that is well maintained. For weight and height measurements, refer to the PhenX Height and Weight Measures. (Note: for consistency, this sentence has been modified to reference PhenX measures, instead of the reference in the original protocol) 2 Select the appropriate growth chart Select the growth chart to use based on the age and sex of the child being weighed and measured. Enter the child's name and the record number, if appropriate. (inst1_221201)
Patient Name (growth_chart_patient_name)
tbl 221201 one (tbl_221201_one)

3 Record data After selecting the appropriate chart and entering the patient's name and record number, if appropriate, complete the data entry table. First, record information about factors obtained at the initial visit that influence growth (inst2_221201)
Patient Record Number (growth_chart_patient_record_number)
Mother of Patient Stature (growth_chart_mothers_stature)
Father of Patient Stature (growth_chart_fathers_stature)
Child's Gestational Age (growth_chart_gestational_age)
Child's Date of Birth (growth_chart_date_of_birth)
Child's Birth Weight (growth_chart_birth_weight)
Child's Birth length (growth_chart_birth_length)
Notable comments on birth (growth_chart_notable_comments)
Today's date (growth_chart_todays_date)
Child's age today (growth_chart_childs_age)
Child's weight today (growth_chart_current_weight)
Child's length/stature today (growth_chart_current_lengthstature)
Notable comments on current growth (growth_chart_current_notable_comments)

Example of how to calculate the child's age: To calculate Sam's age, subtract his birth date from the date of the visit or measurement. To subtract, it will be necessary to convert months to days and years to months if either the month or day in the birth data is larger than in the date of measurements. When converting one month to days, subtract 1 from the number of months in the date of measurement, then add 28, 30, or 31, as appropriate, to the number of days. When converting one year to months, subtract 1 from the number of years in the date of measurement, then add 12 to the number of months. (tbl_221201_two)

Sam is aged 3 years, 6 months, and 19 days. 4 Calculate BMI when a child is aged 2 to 20 years BMI is calculated using weight and stature measurements, then used to compare a child's weight relative to stature with other children of the same age and sex in the reference population. Using a calculator, handheld device or software, determine BMI using the calculation below. The Rare Genetic Conditions WG slightly revised the below calculation and added the example (inst3_221201)
BMI = [Weight (kg) / (Stature (cm) x Stature (cm))] x 10,000 (growth_chart_current_bmi)

Or BMI = [Weight (lb) / (Stature (in) x Stature (in))] x 703 For example: If an individual's weight is 70kg and their stature is 180cm, then their BMI would be calculated as follows: BMI = [Weight (kg) / (Stature (cm) x Stature (cm))] x 10,000 BMI = [ 70 kg / (180 cm x 180 cm)] x 10,000 = [70 / 32,400] x 10,000 = 0.002160 x 10,000 = 21.60 It is necessary to convert the weight and stature measurements to the appropriate decimal value shown in Table 1. Example: 37 lbs. 4 oz. = 37.25 lbs., 411/2 inches = 41.5 in (inst4_2212201)
Table 1. Decimal Conversions (tbl_221201_three)

Enter BMI to one place after the decimal point (Example: 15.204 = 15.2). For more information and additional resources on calculating BMI, see Using the CDC BMIforage Growth Charts for Children and Teens Aged 2 to 20 Years at "http://www.cdc.gov/nccdphp/dnpa/growthcharts/training/modules/module1/text/page1a.htm" www.cdc.gov/nccdphp/dnpa/growthcharts/training/modules/module1/text/page1a.htm 5 Plot measurements On the appropriate WHO or CDC growth chart, plot the measurements recorded in the data entry table for the current visit. Find the child's age on the horizontal axis. When plotting weightforlength, find the length on the horizontal axis. Use a straight edge or rightangle ruler to draw a vertical line up from that point. Find the appropriate measurement (weight, length, stature, or BMI) on the vertical axis. Use a straight edge or rightangle ruler to draw a horizontal line across from that point until it intersects the vertical line. Make a small dot where the two lines intersect (inst5_2212201)
Short Stature table (growth_chart_short_stature)
Low Weight Table (growth_chart_low_weightforlength)
High Weight Table (growth_chart_high_weightforlength)
BMI for Age Obeese (growth_chart_obesity)
BMI for Age Overweight (growth_chart_overweight)

6 Interpret the plotted measurements The curved lines on the growth chart show selected percentiles that indicate the rank of the child's measurement. For example, when the dot is plotted on the 95th percentile line on the CDC BMIforage growth chart, it means that 5 of 100 children (5%) of the same age and sex in the reference population have a higher BMIforage. The WHO growth standard charts use the 2nd and the 98th percentiles as the outer most percentile cutoff values indicating abnormal growth. The CDC growth reference charts use the 5th and the 95th percentiles as the outermost percentile cutoff values indicating abnormal growth. Interpret the plotted measurements based on the percentile ranking on the WHO or the CDC growth charts and the percentile cutoff value corresponding to the nutrition indicator shown in the table below. If the percentile rank indicates a nutritionrelated health concern, additional monitoring and assessment are recommended. Determine the percentile rank. Determine if the percentile rank suggests that the anthropometric index is indicative of nutritional risk based on the percentile cutoff value. Compare today's percentile rank with the rank from previous visits to identify any major shifts in the child's growth pattern and the need for further assessment. When transitioning from the WHO growth charts to the CDC growth charts at aged 2 years, a change in growth classification may occur. During this transition, caution should be used in interpreting any changes in classification (inst7_221201)
tbl 221201 four (tbl_221201_four)

Cerebral palsy: Growth charts are available for indivduals with cerebral palsy at the Life Expectancy Project's website: "http://www.lifeexpectancy.org/articles/NewGrowthCharts.shtml" www.lifeexpectancy.org/articles/NewGrowthCharts.shtml This site contains weight-for-age, height-for-age, and BMI-for-age growth charts, for individuals age 2 to 20 years old. The charts are strafied by gender and the Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS). Additionally, there are separate charts for individuals with a level 5 GMFCS who require a feeding tube and those who do not require a feeding tube. Note: the proper use of growth charts require an accurate height and weight of the individual. The Rare Genetic Conditions Working Group recommends investigators use the height and weight measures in the PhenX Toolkit, if they do not have an individual's height/weight. Achondroplasia: Growth charts are available for individuals with achondroplasia at the Little People of America's (LPA) Medical Resource Center website. The charts are separated by gender and the age range is 0-18 years (depending upon the feature which is being plotted). There are charts to plot height for age, head circumference, segmental growth, and other measurements. See the "Specific Instructions" section for the Rare Genetic Conditions Working Group's suggestions regarding other measurements. The growth charts listed below are specific to individuals with achondroplasia. These charts are available via the links below and also on the LPA Medical Resource Center website. A. "https://www.phenxtoolkit.org/toolkit_content/supplemental_info/rare_genetic_conditions/additional_info/A_Growth_Charts_Achondroplasia_Height_for_Age_Males.pdf" Growth Charts: Achondroplasia Height for Age: ..TRUNCATED(inst77_221201)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The World Health Organization (WHO) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) growth charts include both standard graph lines and a series of percentile curves that demonstrate the distribution of certain body measurements in individuals. Each growth chart may illustrate a specific gender and age range. The percentile curves on each chart depend on which measurement is being recorded. The percentile curves on the WHO and CDC growth charts are for individuals who appear to be unaffected by a condition impacting growth. To provide information for special populations, growth charts for specific conditions have been developed; these growth charts contain percentile curves for the distribution of body measurements in individuals with the specific condition. Some conditions with a specific growth chart are cerebral palsy, achondroplasia, Turner syndrome, and Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).

form.longName: PhenX PX220401 - Child Oral Health Pain
form.preferredDefinition: The Child Oral Health Impact Profile-Short Form 19 (COHIP-SF 19) is a 19-item interviewer-administered questionnaire about the oral health of a child to assess the child's quality of life. This questionnaire can be administered to children aged 8-17 years old. The COHIP-SF 19 is derived from the Child Oral Health Impact Profile, which is administered to parents and contains 34 questions. The COHIP-SF 19 covers the areas of school environment, self-image, social-emotional well-being, and functional well-being.

question.questionText: Have you had pain in your teeth/toothache because of your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_toothache)
Have you Had discolored teeth or spots on your teeth because of your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_discolored_teeth)
Have you Had crooked teeth or spaces between your teeth because of your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_crooked_spaces)
Have you Had bad breath because of your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_bad_breath)
Have you Had bleeding gums because of your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_bleding_gums)
Have you Had difficulty eating foods you would like to eat because of your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_difficulty_eating)
Have you Had trouble sleeping because of your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_trouble_sleeping)
Have you had difficulty saying certain words because of your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_difficulty_words)
Have you had difficulty keeping your teeth clean because of your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_difficulty_cleaningteeth)
Have you been unhappy or sad because of your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_unhappy_beensad)
Have felt worried or anxious because of your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_felt_worriedanxious)
Have you avoided smiling or laughing with other children because of your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_avoided_smiling)
Have you felt that you look different because of your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_felt_look_different)
Have you been worried about what other people think about your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_worried_whatpeoplethink)
Have you been teased, bullied, or called names by other children because of your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_been_teased)
Have you missed school for any reason because of your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_missed_school)
Have you not wanted to speak/read out loud in class because of your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_avoided_speakingclass)
Have you been confident because of your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_been_confident)
Have you felt that you were attractive (good looking) because of your teeth, mouth, or face? (child_oral_pain_felt_attractive)

Scoring: The negatively worded items are then reverse coded so that higher scores represent a more positive QOL. Most of the items are negatively worded, so the only 2 items that do not need to be reverse coded are 'been confident' and 'felt that you were attractive' Original code: ('never'=0, 'almost never'=1, 'sometimes'=2, 'fairly often'=3, 'almost all of the time'=4) To reverse code: ('never'=4, 'almost never'=3, 'sometimes'=2, 'fairly often'=1, 'almost all of the time'=0) Totals: Calculated as the total sum of the items in each subscale COHIPSF 19 Total is the total sum of all 19 items For missing items: do not calculate subscales with missing items or total scale (scoring_220401)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Child Oral Health Impact Profile-Short Form 19 (COHIP-SF 19) is a 19-item interviewer-administered questionnaire about the oral health of a child to assess the child's quality of life. This questionnaire can be administered to children aged 8-17 years old. The COHIP-SF 19 is derived from the Child Oral Health Impact Profile, which is administered to parents and contains 34 questions. The COHIP-SF 19 covers the areas of school environment, self-image, social-emotional well-being, and functional well-being.
